In this paper, we presented the first systematic study of the privacy properties of the advertising systems of five popular search engines: Two traditional ones, Google and Bing, and three private ones, DuckDuckGo, StartPage, and Qwant.

We propose an automated methodology to study the impact of clicking on search ads on three popular private search engines which have advertising-based business models: StartPage, Qwant, and DuckDuckGo, and we compare them to two dominant dataharvesting ones: Google and Bing.

In this work, we aim to fill this gap by conducting the first study of the privacy properties of the advertising systems of three major privacy-focused search engines: DuckDuckGo, StartPage, and Qwant, and how they compare to more popular search engines: Bing and Google.

Alarmingly, we observe that privacy-focused search engines engage in more navigation-based tracking than non-privacy-focused ones: We observe navigational tracking on 4% ad clicks on Bing, on 100% ad clicks on Google, on 100% ad clicks on DuckDuckGo, on 86% ad clicks on Qwant, and on 100% ad clicks on StartPage.

However, private search engines rely on advertising for revenue, and use traditional advertising platforms to deliver ads: DuckDuckGo and Qwant use Microsoft's advertising system, while StartPage uses Google's advertising system.

In this paper, we presented the first systematic study of the privacy properties of the advertising systems of five popular search engines: Two traditional ones, Google and Bing, and three private ones, DuckDuckGo, StartPage, and Qwant.

Broken down by search engine, we observed 277, 218, 326, 437, and 260 different tracker third parties over all iterations, and a median of 9, 11, 6, 8, and 6 different online trackers per iteration for Bing, Google, DuckDuckGo, StartPage, and Qwant, respectively.

In this paper, we presented the first systematic study of the privacy properties of the advertising systems of five popular search engines: Two traditional ones, Google and Bing, and three private ones, DuckDuckGo, StartPage, and Qwant.

We measure this by loading the website each clicked search advertisement leads to, recording the URLs of all sub-resources and network requests made when loading and executing the page, and comparing those URLs against EasyList and EasyPrivacy.

Alarmingly, we observe that privacy-focused search engines engage in more navigation-based tracking than non-privacy-focused ones: We observe navigational tracking on 4% ad clicks on Bing, on 100% ad clicks on Google, on 100% ad clicks on DuckDuckGo, on 86% ad clicks on Qwant, and on 100% ad clicks on StartPage.

While the navigation tracking that occurs when users click on ads on traditional search engines appears to cause little privacy harm, as users are identified by sites operated by third-party entities in only 4% and 8% of navigation paths for Bing and Google, respectively.

In this work, we aim to fill this gap by conducting the first study of the privacy properties of the advertising systems of three major privacy-focused search engines: DuckDuckGo, StartPage, and Qwant, and how they compare to more popular search engines: Bing and Google.

We propose an automated methodology to study the impact of clicking on search ads on three popular private search engines which have advertising-based business models: StartPage, Qwant, and DuckDuckGo, and we compare them to two dominant dataharvesting ones: Google and Bing.

We study the two dominant search engines that rely on user tracking for personalized search results and advertisements, namely Google and Bing, and three of the most popular privacy-branded search engines that provide users with non-personalized results and ads: DuckDuckGo, StartPage, and Qwant [11,29].

In this work, we aim to fill this gap by conducting the first study of the privacy properties of the advertising systems of three major privacy-focused search engines: DuckDuckGo, StartPage, and Qwant, and how they compare to more popular search engines: Bing and Google.

We propose an automated methodology to study the impact of clicking on search ads on three popular private search engines which have advertising-based business models: StartPage, Qwant, and DuckDuckGo, and we compare them to two dominant dataharvesting ones: Google and Bing.

Alarmingly, we observe that privacy-focused search engines engage in more navigation-based tracking than non-privacy-focused ones: We observe navigational tracking on 4% ad clicks on Bing, on 100% ad clicks on Google, on 100% ad clicks on DuckDuckGo, on 86% ad clicks on Qwant, and on 100% ad clicks on StartPage.

We study the two dominant search engines that rely on user tracking for personalized search results and advertisements, namely Google and Bing, and three of the most popular privacy-branded search engines that provide users with non-personalized results and ads: DuckDuckGo, StartPage, and Qwant [11,29].

For instance, Hannak et al. [23] have developed a methodology for measuring personalization in search results, applied it to Bing, Google, and DuckDuckGo, and found that Bing results are more personalized than Google ones while they did not find any noticeable personalization for DuckDuckGo.

We study the two dominant search engines that rely on user tracking for personalized search results and advertisements, namely Google and Bing, and three of the most popular privacy-branded search engines that provide users with non-personalized results and ads: DuckDuckGo, StartPage, and Qwant [11,29].

Alarmingly, we observe that privacy-focused search engines engage in more navigation-based tracking than non-privacy-focused ones: We observe navigational tracking on 4% ad clicks on Bing, on 100% ad clicks on Google, on 100% ad clicks on DuckDuckGo, on 86% ad clicks on Qwant, and on 100% ad clicks on StartPage.
